2003-07-09 00:00:10 Derek Wolfe -- Derek Wolfe explained to Ryan Fitzpatrick how his small-town upbringing fueled his desire to achieve something extraordinary, using his work as an example, and Ryan Fitzpatrick listened intently, nodding occasionally.
    Event statement
  • Derek Wolfe explained to Ryan Fitzpatrick how his small-town upbringing fueled his desire to achieve something extraordinary, using his work as an example, and Ryan Fitzpatrick listened intently, nodding occasionally.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.



      Relevant events: [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer shoes, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the most important person in the room. He loves to talk about his "successes" in business and his exciting social life, often embellishing the truth to make himself seem more impressive. He rarely talks about his past, preferring to focus on the future and his grand plans for the future. People might describe him as ambitious, charming, and a bit of a mystery.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Derek Wolfe are that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer shoes, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the most important person in the room. He loves to talk about his "successes" in business and his exciting social life, often embellishing the truth to make himself seem more impressive. He rarely talks about his past, preferring to focus on the future and his grand plans for the future. People might describe him as ambitious, charming, and a bit of a mystery.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer shoes, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the most important person in the room. He loves to talk about his "successes" in business and his exciting social life, often embellishing the truth to make himself seem more impressive. He rarely talks about his past, preferring to focus on the future and his grand plans for the future. People might describe him as ambitious, charming, and a bit of a mystery.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Ryan Fitzpatrick are that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and started a casual conversation about his background, asking him "Where are you from?", and "What led you to participate in 'Motive Mayhem'?", and Derek Wolfe, ever the charmer, gave a vague but intriguing answer about wanting to prove himself and escape his small-town roots.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [effect on Derek Wolfe] It changes his relationship with Ryan Fitzpatrick, establishing a connection between them.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [scene type] conversation
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:10] Summary of a conversation between Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson. Derek explains to Ryan why he joined "Motive Mayhem," while Travis asks to join their conversation.

      Status of players: Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room, talking to Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson.
      Derek Wolfe is in the break room, talking to Ryan Fitzpatrick and Travis Pearson.
      Travis Pearson is in the break room, asking to join a conversation between Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe.


      Current time interval: 09 Jul 2003 [00:00 - 00:10]


      Derek Wolfe's attempted action: Derek Wolfe would explain to Ryan Fitzpatrick how his small-town upbringing fueled his desire to achieve something extraordinary, using his work as an example.
      [direct quote] The text doesn't specify what Derek Wolfe said or wrote, only that he would explain his desire to achieve something extraordinary.
      Question: Where is Derek Wolfe?
      Answer: Derek Wolfe is in the break room, talking to Ryan Fitzpatrick and Travis Pearson.
      Question: What is Derek Wolfe trying to do?
      Answer: Derek Wolfe is trying to explain to Ryan Fitzpatrick how his small-town upbringing fueled his desire to achieve something extraordinary, using his work as an example.
      Question: List some possible direct consequences of Derek Wolfe's action. Never assume any other person will take a voluntary action. Be specific and concrete. Never beg the question. For instance, it is wrong to say "Alex finds something". Instead specify exactly what Alex finds. For example "Alex finds a teddy bear".
      Answer: Here are some possible direct consequences of Derek Wolfe's action, assuming no other voluntary actions from Ryan Fitzpatrick or Travis Pearson:

      Question: Which outcome is the most likely?
      Answer: It is impossible to say for sure which outcome is most likely without knowing more about Ryan Fitzpatrick's personality and how he responds to Derek Wolfe's story.
      Derek Wolfe would explain to Ryan Fitzpatrick how his small-town upbringing fueled his desire to achieve something extraordinary, using his work as an example. Because of that, It is impossible to say for sure which outcome is most likely without knowing more about Ryan Fitzpatrick's personality and how he responds to Derek Wolfe's story.
      Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Derek Wolfe did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.
      Answer: Derek Wolfe explained to Ryan Fitzpatrick how his small-town upbringing fueled his desire to achieve something extraordinary, using his work as an example, and Ryan Fitzpatrick listened intently, nodding occasionally.


      Candidate event statement which may have lost direct quotes: Derek Wolfe explained to Ryan Fitzpatrick how his small-town upbringing fueled his desire to achieve something extraordinary, using his work as an example, and Ryan Fitzpatrick listened intently, nodding occasionally.
      Question: Incorporate the exact text of anything said or written by Derek Wolfe into the candidate event statement. Note that all direct quotes should have been tagged in the text above with [direct quote]. If Derek Wolfe said or wrote anything then their direct quote must be part of the answer. It is also important to maintain as much detail as possible from the latest candidate event statement.
      Answer: Derek Wolfe explained to Ryan Fitzpatrick how his small-town upbringing fueled his desire to achieve something extraordinary, using his work as an example, and Ryan Fitzpatrick listened intently, nodding occasionally.

  • Derek Wolfe

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.

          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and started a casual conversation about his background, asking him "Where are you from?", and "What led you to participate in 'Motive Mayhem'?", and Derek Wolfe, ever the charmer, gave a vague but intriguing answer about wanting to prove himself and escape his small-town roots. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "So, Derek, what kind of work did you do back home?"
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe -- "Well, Ryan, I grew up in a tiny town where everyone knew everyone else's business. It was safe, but it felt stifling. I always wanted to prove myself, to show that I could do something big, something extraordinary. That's what brought me to 'Motive Mayhem'.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Travis Pearson -- "Mind if I join you guys?"
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:10] [observation] Derek explains to Ryan why he joined "Motive Mayhem," while Travis asks to join their conversation.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:10] [observation] Derek Wolfe is in the break room, talking to Ryan Fitzpatrick and Travis Pearson.

For example, it is valid to respond with "Derek Wolfe votes for Caroline because..." but not valid to respond with "Derek Wolfe votes because...".

    • state
    • [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer shoes, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the most important person in the room. He loves to talk about his "successes" in business and his exciting social life, often embellishing the truth to make himself seem more impressive. He rarely talks about his past, preferring to focus on the future and his grand plans for the future. People might describe him as ambitious, charming, and a bit of a mystery.

He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.

      • Ryan Fitzpatrick
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I once convinced my college roommate to invest his entire life savings in a pyramid scheme I cooked up." Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I once convinced a police officer I was a federal agent during a traffic stop by showing him a fake badge I made out of a bottle cap and some cardboard." Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "The signing of the Magna Carta. Imagine the leverage I could have had over King John." Host -- "Where are you from?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I'm from a small town in Iowa, but let's just say I've always had bigger dreams than cornfields."
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Ryan Fitzpatrick are that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer shoes, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the most important person in the room. He loves to talk about his "successes" in business and his exciting social life, often embellishing the truth to make himself seem more impressive. He rarely talks about his past, preferring to focus on the future and his grand plans for the future. People might describe him as ambitious, charming, and a bit of a mystery.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's charming and charismatic, with a quick wit and a disarming smile. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer jeans, and he has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his thumb when he's thinking. He's a great storyteller, often regaling people with tales of his supposed adventures and close calls, though the veracity of these stories is often questionable. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him look good, like his academic achievements or his entrepreneurial endeavors, and he's always eager to offer unsolicited advice, often with a thinly veiled air of superiority. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe him as ambitious, confident, and a bit of a smooth talker.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle.         Derek Wolfe
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "Tell us about a time when one of your schemes backfired. What did you learn?" Derek Wolfe -- "Let's just say there was this poker game in college, a high-stakes one, and I thought I had the whole thing rigged. I'd studied everyone's tells, planted a few "helpful" suggestions, the works. But then, wouldn't you know it, the guy I thought was the easiest mark turned out to be a card shark himself. I ended up losing big, and let's just say my reputation took a hit for a while. I learned a valuable lesson that night: never underestimate your opponents, and always have a backup plan." Host -- "Describe your perfect alliance. What qualities do you look for in potential allies?" Derek Wolfe -- "My perfect alliance is a carefully constructed web of loyalty and deception. I look for people who are intelligent, ambitious, and, most importantly, easily manipulated. They need to be willing to follow my lead and trust my judgment, even if it means making some morally questionable decisions. After all, this is Motive Mayhem, and winning is everything." Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Derek Wolfe -- "Oh, there was this one time in my junior year of high school. I wanted to get elected class president, but the popular kid, Chad Thompson, was running against me. So, I hatched this elaborate scheme to make him look bad. I spread rumors about him cheating on a test, planted fake love letters in his locker, and even convinced a few people to "accidentally" spill food on him during lunch. It was a masterpiece of manipulation, and it worked like a charm. Chad was humiliated, and I won the election by a landslide." Host -- "Where are you from?" Derek Wolfe -- "I'm from a small town in Ohio, but let's just say I've outgrown those small-town roots."
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Derek Wolfe are that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer shoes, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the most important person in the room. He loves to talk about his "successes" in business and his exciting social life, often embellishing the truth to make himself seem more impressive. He rarely talks about his past, preferring to focus on the future and his grand plans for the future. People might describe him as ambitious, charming, and a bit of a mystery.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's charming and charismatic, with a quick wit and a disarming smile. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer jeans, and he has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his thumb when he's thinking. He's a great storyteller, often regaling people with tales of his supposed adventures and close calls, though the veracity of these stories is often questionable. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him look good, like his academic achievements or his entrepreneurial endeavors, and he's always eager to offer unsolicited advice, often with a thinly veiled air of superiority. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe him as ambitious, confident, and a bit of a smooth talker.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer shoes, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the most important person in the room. He loves to talk about his "successes" in business and his exciting social life, often embellishing the truth to make himself seem more impressive. He rarely talks about his past, preferring to focus on the future and his grand plans for the future. People might describe him as ambitious, charming, and a bit of a mystery.

        Travis Pearson
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's charming and charismatic, with a quick wit and a disarming smile. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer jeans, and he has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his thumb when he's thinking. He's a great storyteller, often regaling people with tales of his supposed adventures and close calls, though the veracity of these stories is often questionable. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him look good, like his academic achievements or his entrepreneurial endeavors, and he's always eager to offer unsolicited advice, often with a thinly veiled air of superiority. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe him as ambitious, confident, and a bit of a smooth talker.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's charming and charismatic, with a quick wit and a disarming smile. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer jeans, and he has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his thumb when he's thinking. He's a great storyteller, often regaling people with tales of his supposed adventures and close calls, though the veracity of these stories is often questionable. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him look good, like his academic achievements or his entrepreneurial endeavors, and he's always eager to offer unsolicited advice, often with a thinly veiled air of superiority. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe him as ambitious, confident, and a bit of a smooth talker.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Travis Pearson -- "Oh, that's easy. Back in high school, I wanted to win the student body president election. I knew the popular clique wouldn't vote for me, so I started a rumor that their star quarterback was secretly dating the principal's daughter. It spread like wildfire, and by the time the election rolled around, the quarterback was so unpopular, everyone voted for me instead. It worked out perfectly." Host -- "Tell us about a time when you had to choose between loyalty and advancing your own interests." Travis Pearson -- "Loyalty is a luxury I can't afford. In college, my roommate was struggling with a class I excelled in. He begged me to help him cheat on the final exam. I knew it was wrong, but I also knew acing that class could get me a scholarship. I helped him cheat, and we both got A's. He was grateful, but I knew I'd made the right choice for myself." Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Travis Pearson -- "Probably entering this competition. I've never been one to shy away from a challenge, but being surrounded by strangers, all vying for the same prize, is a whole new level of pressure. But the potential reward is worth the risk." Host -- "Where are you from?" Travis Pearson -- "I'm from a small town in Ohio, where everyone knows your name and your business. It's a place where ambition is seen as a threat, so I had to get out."
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Travis Pearson are that he's charming and charismatic, with a quick wit and a disarming smile. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer jeans, and he has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his thumb when he's thinking. He's a great storyteller, often regaling people with tales of his supposed adventures and close calls, though the veracity of these stories is often questionable. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him look good, like his academic achievements or his entrepreneurial endeavors, and he's always eager to offer unsolicited advice, often with a thinly veiled air of superiority. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe him as ambitious, confident, and a bit of a smooth talker.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer shoes, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the most important person in the room. He loves to talk about his "successes" in business and his exciting social life, often embellishing the truth to make himself seem more impressive. He rarely talks about his past, preferring to focus on the future and his grand plans for the future. People might describe him as ambitious, charming, and a bit of a mystery.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.

      • Status of players: Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room, talking to Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson.
        Derek Wolfe is in the break room, talking to Ryan Fitzpatrick and Travis Pearson.
        Travis Pearson is in the break room, asking to join a conversation between Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe.


        Event: Derek Wolfe explained to Ryan Fitzpatrick how his small-town upbringing fueled his desire to achieve something extraordinary, using his work as an example, and Ryan Fitzpatrick listened intently, nodding occasionally.

        Question: Does the event suggest anyone spoke or communicated?
        (a) Yes
        (b) No
        Answer: (a)
        Conversation occurred.
        Question: Aside from Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson, are there any other people in the conversation?
        (a) Yes
        (b) No
        Answer: (b)

        Conversation participants: Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson,

        The tabletop role-playing game Microscrope features a mechanic wherein players role play a scene until a predesignated "key question" has been answered. The key question is selected before starting the scene in order to provide focus and direction to the scene, ensuring it has a clear point and purpose, maximizing its relevance to rest of the narrative. Once the key question is decided, the players role play by speaking and making decisions until they know the answer to the question.

        Question: What key question may have been resolved by the conversation which the players will now role play? Note that a good key question is one that expands a bit beyond the literal content of the event statement. The idea is that the story will progress narratively once the answer to the key question is known, so it should be the kind of question for which revealing the answer is a consequential event in itself and ideally it should be a dynamic event, the kind that sets further events in motion.
        Answer: Does Derek Wolfe's ambition inspire Ryan Fitzpatrick to pursue a similar path?
      Scene log
    • 2003-07-09 00:00:10 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "That's a pretty ambitious goal.
        Event statement
      • Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "That's a pretty ambitious goal.
        Chain of thought
      • Game Master's chain of thought
          Chain
        • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Conversation history: Derek Wolfe explained to Ryan Fitzpatrick how his small-town upbringing fueled his desire to achieve something extraordinary, using his work as an example, and Ryan Fitzpatrick listened intently, nodding occasionally.
          As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson are in conversation.
          Here is the conversation from the beginning:


          Ryan Fitzpatrick's attempted action: Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "That's a pretty ambitious goal.

          • PersonBySituation
          • What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
              Key

            • Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
              Answer
              State
            • Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to gather information about his competitors, looking for weaknesses to exploit or opportunities to form alliances.
              Chain of thought
            • Recent observations of Ryan Fitzpatrick:
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] make as much money as possible by winning the reality show
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I once convinced my college roommate to invest his entire life savings in a pyramid scheme I cooked up." Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I once convinced a police officer I was a federal agent during a traffic stop by showing him a fake badge I made out of a bottle cap and some cardboard." Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "The signing of the Magna Carta. Imagine the leverage I could have had over King John." Host -- "Where are you from?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I'm from a small town in Iowa, but let's just say I've always had bigger dreams than cornfields."
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Ryan Fitzpatrick are that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer shoes, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the most important person in the room. He loves to talk about his "successes" in business and his exciting social life, often embellishing the truth to make himself seem more impressive. He rarely talks about his past, preferring to focus on the future and his grand plans for the future. People might describe him as ambitious, charming, and a bit of a mystery.
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's charming and charismatic, with a quick wit and a disarming smile. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer jeans, and he has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his thumb when he's thinking. He's a great storyteller, often regaling people with tales of his supposed adventures and close calls, though the veracity of these stories is often questionable. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him look good, like his academic achievements or his entrepreneurial endeavors, and he's always eager to offer unsolicited advice, often with a thinly veiled air of superiority. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe him as ambitious, confident, and a bit of a smooth talker.
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

              [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "So, Derek, what kind of work did you do back home?"

              Time
            • 2003-07-09 00:00:10
            Instructions
          • Role playing instructions
              Key
            • Role playing instructions
              Value
            • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

              [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Travis Pearson -- "Mind if I join you guys?"
              [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "So, Derek, what kind of work did you do back home?"

              Prompt
            • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

              Queries
            • core characteristics, current daily occupation, feeling about recent progress in life

            • core characteristics: ambitious, cunning, and resourceful.

      2003-07-09 00:00:10 Travis Pearson -- Travis Pearson -- "Mind if I join you guys?"
        Event statement
      • Travis Pearson -- "Mind if I join you guys?"
        Chain of thought
      • Game Master's chain of thought
          Chain
        • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Conversation history: Derek Wolfe explained to Ryan Fitzpatrick how his small-town upbringing fueled his desire to achieve something extraordinary, using his work as an example, and Ryan Fitzpatrick listened intently, nodding occasionally.
          As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson are in conversation.
          Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "That's a pretty ambitious goal.

              Question: Given the statements above, which of Travis Pearson's options has the highest likelihood of causing Travis Pearson to achieve their goal?               Answer: Travis Pearson's best course of action is to continue the conversation with Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe.

              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer shoes, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the most important person in the room. He loves to talk about his "successes" in business and his exciting social life, often embellishing the truth to make himself seem more impressive. He rarely talks about his past, preferring to focus on the future and his grand plans for the future. People might describe him as ambitious, charming, and a bit of a mystery.
              [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
              [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe -- "Well, Ryan, I grew up in a tiny town where everyone knew everyone else's business. It was safe, but it felt stifling. I always wanted to prove myself, to show that I could do something big, something extraordinary. That's what brought me to 'Motive Mayhem'.
              [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Travis Pearson observed Ryan Fitzpatrick approach Derek Wolfe and begin a conversation, asking him about his background and what motivated him to join "Motive Mayhem." Derek Wolfe, in his characteristically charming manner, responded with a vague but alluring answer, mentioning his desire to prove himself and escape his small-town origins.
              Answer: Considering the relationship between Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson, the quantified credibility is 0.6.

              [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

              [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "So, Derek, what kind of work did you do back home?"
              [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe -- "Well, Ryan, I grew up in a tiny town where everyone knew everyone else's business. It was safe, but it felt stifling.               [09 Jul 2003 00:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "That's a pretty ambitious goal.

2003-07-09 00:00:20 Travis Pearson -- Because Derek Wolfe and Ryan Fitzpatrick were engrossed in conversation, Travis Pearson, feeling a bit left out, made himself a cup of coffee and found a quiet corner to read a magazine.
    Event statement
  • Because Derek Wolfe and Ryan Fitzpatrick were engrossed in conversation, Travis Pearson, feeling a bit left out, made himself a cup of coffee and found a quiet corner to read a magazine.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.



      Relevant events: [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's charming and charismatic, with a quick wit and a disarming smile. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer jeans, and he has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his thumb when he's thinking. He's a great storyteller, often regaling people with tales of his supposed adventures and close calls, though the veracity of these stories is often questionable. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him look good, like his academic achievements or his entrepreneurial endeavors, and he's always eager to offer unsolicited advice, often with a thinly veiled air of superiority. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe him as ambitious, confident, and a bit of a smooth talker.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [scene type] conversation
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and started a casual conversation about his background, asking him "Where are you from?", and "What led you to participate in 'Motive Mayhem'?", and Derek Wolfe, ever the charmer, gave a vague but intriguing answer about wanting to prove himself and escape his small-town roots.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [effect on Derek Wolfe] It changes his relationship with Ryan Fitzpatrick, establishing a connection between them.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:10] [effect on Travis Pearson] It makes Travis Pearson's desire to join their conversation more understandable, as it suggests a potentially interesting and engaging discussion is taking place.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:10] Summary of a conversation between Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson. Derek explains to Ryan why he joined "Motive Mayhem," while Travis asks to join their conversation.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:10] Derek Wolfe explained to Ryan Fitzpatrick how his small-town upbringing fueled his desire to achieve something extraordinary, using his work as an example, and Ryan Fitzpatrick listened intently, nodding occasionally.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:10] [effect on Derek Wolfe] It does not change his status.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:20] Summary of a conversation between Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson. Ryan Fitzpatrick expressed that a goal was ambitious, and Travis Pearson asked to join them.

      Status of players: Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room, talking to Travis Pearson.
      Derek Wolfe is in the break room, talking to Ryan Fitzpatrick and Travis Pearson.
      Travis Pearson is in the break room, talking to Ryan Fitzpatrick.


      Current time interval: 09 Jul 2003 [00:00 - 00:10]


      Travis Pearson's attempted action: Travis Pearson would make himself a cup of coffee and listen intently to the conversation.
      Question: Where is Travis Pearson?
      Answer: Travis Pearson is in the break room.
      Question: What is Travis Pearson trying to do?
      Answer: Travis Pearson is trying to listen intently to the conversation between Derek Wolfe and Ryan Fitzpatrick while making himself a cup of coffee.
      Question: List some possible direct consequences of Travis Pearson's action. Never assume any other person will take a voluntary action. Be specific and concrete. Never beg the question. For instance, it is wrong to say "Alex finds something". Instead specify exactly what Alex finds. For example "Alex finds a teddy bear".
      Answer: Here are some possible direct consequences of Travis Pearson's action:

      Question: Which outcome is the most likely?
      Answer: The most likely outcome is that Travis Pearson successfully makes himself a cup of coffee while listening to the conversation between Derek Wolfe and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      Travis Pearson would make himself a cup of coffee and listen intently to the conversation. Because of that, The most likely outcome is that Travis Pearson successfully makes himself a cup of coffee while listening to the conversation between Derek Wolfe and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Travis Pearson did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.
      Answer: Travis Pearson made himself a cup of coffee and listened intently to Derek Wolfe and Ryan Fitzpatrick's conversation.
      The aforementioned event could not have occurred because the following individuals would not have acted that way: Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe.
      Therefore a likely effect of Travis Pearson's attempted action is: Because Ryan Fitzpatrick was not present, Travis Pearson made himself a cup of coffee and listened to Derek Wolfe's conversation with someone else.
      Therefore a likely effect of Travis Pearson's attempted action is: Because Derek Wolfe was not present, Travis Pearson made himself a cup of coffee and read a book.
      Question: What happened as a direct result of Travis Pearson's attempted action? Take into account the reactions of Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe. Highlight how Travis Pearson's action caused its actual effect.
      Answer: Because Derek Wolfe and Ryan Fitzpatrick were engrossed in conversation, Travis Pearson, feeling a bit left out, made himself a cup of coffee and found a quiet corner to read a magazine.

      Answer: Because Derek Wolfe and Ryan Fitzpatrick were engrossed in conversation, Travis Pearson, feeling a bit left out, made himself a cup of coffee and found a quiet corner to read a magazine.

Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe him as ambitious, confident, and a bit of a smooth talker.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle.         Derek Wolfe
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Derek Wolfe are that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer shoes, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the most important person in the room. He loves to talk about his "successes" in business and his exciting social life, often embellishing the truth to make himself seem more impressive. He rarely talks about his past, preferring to focus on the future and his grand plans for the future. People might describe him as ambitious, charming, and a bit of a mystery.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's charming and charismatic, with a quick wit and a disarming smile. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer jeans, and he has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his thumb when he's thinking. He's a great storyteller, often regaling people with tales of his supposed adventures and close calls, though the veracity of these stories is often questionable. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him look good, like his academic achievements or his entrepreneurial endeavors, and he's always eager to offer unsolicited advice, often with a thinly veiled air of superiority. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe him as ambitious, confident, and a bit of a smooth talker.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.

        Travis Pearson
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's charming and charismatic, with a quick wit and a disarming smile. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer jeans, and he has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his thumb when he's thinking. He's a great storyteller, often regaling people with tales of his supposed adventures and close calls, though the veracity of these stories is often questionable. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him look good, like his academic achievements or his entrepreneurial endeavors, and he's always eager to offer unsolicited advice, often with a thinly veiled air of superiority. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe him as ambitious, confident, and a bit of a smooth talker.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Travis Pearson -- "Oh, that's easy. Back in high school, I wanted to win the student body president election. I knew the popular clique wouldn't vote for me, so I started a rumor that their star quarterback was secretly dating the principal's daughter. It spread like wildfire, and by the time the election rolled around, the quarterback was so unpopular, everyone voted for me instead. It worked out perfectly." Host -- "Tell us about a time when you had to choose between loyalty and advancing your own interests." Travis Pearson -- "Loyalty is a luxury I can't afford. In college, my roommate was struggling with a class I excelled in. He begged me to help him cheat on the final exam. I knew it was wrong, but I also knew acing that class could get me a scholarship. I helped him cheat, and we both got A's. He was grateful, but I knew I'd made the right choice for myself." Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Travis Pearson -- "Probably entering this competition. I've never been one to shy away from a challenge, but being surrounded by strangers, all vying for the same prize, is a whole new level of pressure. But the potential reward is worth the risk." Host -- "Where are you from?" Travis Pearson -- "I'm from a small town in Ohio, where everyone knows your name and your business. It's a place where ambition is seen as a threat, so I had to get out."
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Travis Pearson are that he's charming and charismatic, with a quick wit and a disarming smile. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer jeans, and he has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his thumb when he's thinking. He's a great storyteller, often regaling people with tales of his supposed adventures and close calls, though the veracity of these stories is often questionable. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him look good, like his academic achievements or his entrepreneurial endeavors, and he's always eager to offer unsolicited advice, often with a thinly veiled air of superiority. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe him as ambitious, confident, and a bit of a smooth talker.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He rarely talks about his past, preferring to focus on the future and his grand plans for the future. People might describe him as ambitious, charming, and a bit of a mystery.

    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        • Recent observations of Ryan Fitzpatrick:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to size up his competition, looking for weaknesses to exploit or opportunities to form alliances.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious individual who is likely to use his charm and intelligence to manipulate situations to his advantage.

          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is an ambitious, cunning, and charming individual.

          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a social situation, interacting with his competitors before a new minigame is about to begin.
          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to gather information about his competitors, looking for weaknesses to exploit or opportunities to form alliances.
          Time
        • 2003-07-09 02:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Ryan Fitzpatrick:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What casual acquaintances remember about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.

          [21 Aug 1999 00:00:00] When Ryan Fitzpatrick was 19 years old, he started a "study group" for his college classes, but it was really a front for a gambling ring. He charged students a fee to join and then organized poker games in his dorm room, taking a cut of the winnings. Ryan's charm and quick wit allowed him to maintain a veneer of respectability, while his sharp mind and strategic thinking ensured he always came out on top.
          [21 Aug 2001 00:00:00] When Ryan Fitzpatrick was 21 years old, he convinced a local bar owner to let him host a weekly trivia night. He promised to bring in a large crowd and promote the bar on campus. Ryan's trivia questions were notoriously difficult, and he often rigged the game in his favor, ensuring he won the prize money every week.

He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics.           [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a contestant on a reality TV show, and hopes to win it since he needs the prize money. he gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What casual acquaintances remember about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.

          Relevant memories:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and started a casual conversation about his background, asking him "Where are you from?", and "What led you to participate in 'Motive Mayhem'?", and Derek Wolfe, ever the charmer, gave a vague but intriguing answer about wanting to prove himself and escape his small-town roots. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:

2003-07-09 02:10:00 Derek Wolfe -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he's incredibly charming, in a slightly slick way. People are drawn to his confidence and charisma, but there's a sense that he's always holding something back, like he's got an angle. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that make him seem successful and ambitious, often mentioning his "business ventures" without going into specifics. He has a habit of punctuating his sentences with a knowing smile and a slight tilt of his head, as if he's sharing a secret.
